newsitem.title: GERMANY: Further tinplate mergers seen possible in Europe.
newsitem.headline: Further tinplate mergers seen possible in Europe.

text.p: Manufacturers of tinplated steel in Europe may restructure their operations in line with developments in the can-making industry, a statement from the producer-funded promotion agency IZW said.
The leading three consumers which process tinplate into can feedstock now represented two thirds of total European demand while production capacity was still fragmented, it said.
Packaging companies Schmalbach Lubeca /Continental Can Europe (CCE) and Pechiney announced last November they would establish a joint company for metals packaging in 1997.
These canstock companies were operating throughout Europe and in third countries and were able to pursue aggressive cost savings.
While there was only low growth potential in metal packaging demand, tinplate producers, whose number has already shrunk to seven, were still grappling with over-capacity.
"These trends will be the greatest challenge to the tinplate industry in the next few years," the statement quoted Jost Massenberg, board member at Germany's Rasselstein Hoesch GmbH, as saying.
Tinplated steel has captured 55 percent of the beverage can market in Europe and its share has been rising at the expense of aluminium, which was affected by price volatility.
But overall European tinplate demand was merely steady at four million tonnes a year -- out of a global 16 million -- because of material savings and substitution.
In Germany, tinplate demand was falling.
Rasselstein, with a 20 percent share of the European tinplate market, merged its operations with Krupp Hoesch Stahl AG in 1995.
Rasselstein has been exporting 400,000 tonnes a year to third countries, which makes it the leading world exporter.
